qas.question: Closer examination of what information allowed for further progress in scientific knowledge?
Who felt that looking to these ancient documents for new ideas was not the way to mover forward?
What group was neutral about this issue as they felt the subject unimportant?
When did even the scholars and professors began to at least end to examine the works of Aristotle?
What information allowed for less progress in scientific knowledge?
Who felt that looking to these ancient documents for new ideas was the best way to move forward?
What group was neutral about this issue as they felt the subject too important?
Who was always interested in scientific innovation?
Who was forbidden to develop science?

context: Better acquaintance with <b4_0>Greek and Roman <a0_0>technical writings<b4_0/><a0_0/> also influenced the development of <b8_0>European<b8_0/> science (see the history of science in the Renaissance). This was despite what <a1_0><b5_0>A. C. Crombie<b5_0/><a1_0/> (viewing the Renaissance in the 19th-century manner as a chapter in the heroic March of Progress) calls "a backwards-looking admiration for antiquity", in which Platonism stood in opposition to the Aristotelian concentration on the observable properties of the physical world. But <a2_0><b6_0><b7_0>Renaissance humanists<b7_0/><b6_0/><a2_0/>, who considered themselves as restoring the glory and nobility of antiquity, had no interest in scientific innovation. However, by the mid-to-late <a3_0>16th century,<a3_0/> even the universities, though still dominated by Scholasticism, began to demand that Aristotle be read in accurate texts edited according to the principles of Renaissance philology, thus setting the stage for Galileo's quarrels with the outmoded habits of Scholasticism.
